WHAT ARE MORAL ABSOLUTES LIKE?

 

 Jeremy Waldron

 

:: :: ::

 

Thursday April 14th, 4pm

Emerson 105

Harvard Yard

 

:: :: ::

 

The Harvard Review of Philosophy would like to invite everyone to hear Jeremy Waldron (Chichele Professor of Social and Political Theory at All Souls College, Oxford and University Professor of Law, NYU) give our annual lecture on "WHAT ARE MORAL ABSOLUTES LIKE?

This is an opportunity to hear one of the world's most respected moral and legal philosophers speak about a topic of immense relevance to current debates about everything from torture to bioethics. Please join the Harvard Review of Philosophy on Thursday April 14th at Emerson 105, at 4pm. The lecture will be followed by a reception.

Abstract: Recent concern about torture has revived interest in the idea of absolute prohibitions.  Many philosophers tell me that they can make no sense of this idea, because they believe that ultimately the only thing that matters morally is the harm caused and the harm prevented by an action.  In this lecture, I will try to make intelligible the idea of a moral absolute by comparing it with a number of other conceptions, including legal prohibitions, rules of games, exclusionary reasons, divine commands, and ideas of moral taboos.
